title: Local fintech launches new digital currency for trading loans
text:
The structure is one being examined by many global investment banks, which are investing heavily in asset tokenisation, and experimenting with stablecoins (digital currency pegged to fiat money to reduce volatility).

Polymath, a security token developer working with Marketlend, said it believed this could be the first global example of blockchain being used to lift liquidity in a private, secondary loan market.

Mr Tyndall said the structure had been created under its existing Australian Financial Services Licence (AFSL), with advice from a global law firm, and is only being provided to sophisticated, wholesale investors.

"This is the result of many months of research and testing and we believe this will drive greater speed, efficiency and security across the Marketlend platform and its global recognition,” he said.

Marketlend has facilitated $150 million in loans since it was created in 2014; it's a minnow in debtor finance. But the innovation comes as regulators and large financial institutions are examining digital currencies following the announcement of Libra by Facebook and a technology consortium.

The creation of Black will allow Marketlend investors to buy asset tokens on its blockchain, and manage loan contracts on the platform. The digital process will facilitate liquidity and lift transparency because records of investors' holdings can be viewed over Ethereum and verified.

Initially, access to Black will be restricted to investors on Marketlend's platform, but Mr Tyndall said it could offer it to the wider market.

Graeme Moore, head of tokenisation at Polymath, said he expects a proliferation of financial market applications for crypto-assets in the next three to 12 months.

“Given the size of the markets they operate in, the big investment banks won't be the leaders with rolling this out, but they will closely be watch innovation in start-ups, and if these small market use-cases prove themselves, then I expect significant scaling up worldwide,'' he said.

Possible trillion-dollar markets that could develop tokenisation processes include those for cross-border payments, inter-bank lending and foreign exchange, Mr Moore said.

“All these markets are being made more cost effective using blockchain, which will touch all of them in some way".

He said banks that grasp what is happening would profit from the more efficient processes, while those who continue to "send out pieces of paper to people", would become irrelevant.
description: Marketlend has an online marketplace for small business loans, its new digital currency called Black will be backed one-to-one with the Australian dollar.
